texts.shortText: Most often seen in a strongly-grazed form, as narrow gardens surrounding the Pear limpet Scutellasta cochlear. This form consists of prostrate axes with short lateral lobes and is only a few mm tall. Larger plants, not included in limpet gardens, are rare and have soft, fleshy, flattened central axes which give off paired lateral lobes that in turn bear short secondary branches. Colour brownish red.
Grazed specimens are prostrate and form narrow gardens about 10 mm wide around the host limpet, but are only a few mm tall. Un-grazed clumps typically up to about 50 mm long, blades about 1 mm wide.

Global: Endemic to South Africa (Namibian records probably not this species).

Local/Regional: Namaqualand to southern KwaZulu-Natal.

Mostly seen as narrow gardens surrounding the Pear limpet Scutellastra cochlear. The limpets eliminate other algae from their gardens and by ‘mowing’ them (and probably also by fertilizing them with their urine) they stimulate growth of the algae and are able to subsist on a tiny ‘plot’, thus maintaining remarkably high populations densities. The fact that they hardly move, grow very slowly and have a lower reproductive rate than most other limpets also reduced their energy requirements, making them the ‘tortoises’ of the seashore!

Un-grazed plants often seen on the backs of limpets.
Individual tufts often include a mixture of sporophyte and gametophytes stages of the life cycle, as well as juveniles.

One of about 10 regional species in this genus, but most easily recognised by its association with limpets.  Plants growing separate from limpets recognised by their soft texture and strongly-flattened axes.

Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.
